Dear Lost Beyond Pluto, I miss watching your legal analysis and professional translations of all the "legaleze" into layman terms for us. 
I get that you are clearly having much more fun with your current format of talk show with someone you care about and feel comfortable with. It clearly shows, and you look like you are having such a good time. And I want that for you. 

I just miss having your unique and sharp and simple breakdowns of a case that has been so complicated and felt so confusing (the AH/JD case). 
As someone who is still living with long-term consequences of prolonged emotional abuse (it's nearly 20 years later and I am still having a hard time trusting anyone or even functioning as an adult), this case really got to me. Hearing those tapes really punched me in the gut, emotionally. 
One of the things that have been so devastating for me, is that no-one believed me, and that's what I see repeated with Depp. 
...and the let-down and despondency so many victims of abuse felt collectively after the UK ruling...! Well I know I'm not the only one who took that really hard. 

I continue to follow this case because I am so personally invested, but I really miss your expert, clear-cut and qualified analysis and take on the developments. 
I would so much like to hear your opinion on the paper that just came out, using the UK ruling as a case study and minutely and systematically assessing the credibility of AH. The paper is called "Assessment of Credibility of Testimony in Alleged Intimate Partner Violence: A Case Study" and can be found here https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/24732850.2021.1945836

As a woman, I am absolutely appalled by Amber's behavior. This is not how a woman should behave. As a psychologist, I understand she has a myriad of issues and in the end she does what she knows and feels, which by no means is an excuse, as she is fully aware of her actions, as well as difference between right and wrong, good and bad.

This being said, my interest in the cases between Johnny and Amber has showed me that there is still a gender inequality, which instead of being balanced out with the previous attempts of shedding light over all the times women have been subjected to domestic violence, which used to be almost always shunned and disregarded, now we have the pendulum swayed the other direction, where men have been seen as the immediate enemy to women, condemned to be the abusers with or without proof. I believe that the law should always be blind to race, gender, religion, sexual orientation, etc, and such bias should always be strictly avoided, by always focusing on the facts! comment: Looking over this again I ultimately think it was a public policy decision. The judge must have been concerned about raising the standard of evidence too high to the detriment of domestic abuse victims who will frequently not have a solid body of evidence due to the nature of the offences. The Uk courts do not have a good reputation for accommodating the inherent disadvantages domestic abuse victims will face in proving their case in law. And here the court was put on the public stage. The Claimants put in their claim in very strong terms against Amber - ‚Äúnarcissist, psychopath, gold digger‚Äù,  and made the point at the outset that there was no middle ground here - one was a liar and the judge must decide. So it‚Äôs hardly surprising that a 60 something year old judge acting as sole judge and jury, married to a notable woman‚Äôs equality campaigner, would never have the nerve to make a judgement which would inevitably be interpreted as agreeing with such a scathing portrayal of a potential domestic abuse victim before the world. Not in the era of Metoo and following the scandals of a string high profile powerful men who used their means to escape justice for years and threw all sorts of mud at those who spoke out against them. And if a member of the public gives the matter a superficial glance, Amber Heard‚Äôs case looks half-decent. Evidence of injuries, witness statements...a layperson would probably see this briefly in the media and, if Depp succeeded, be surprised that this kind of evidence wasn‚Äôt enough to prove it in a civil court. So they‚Äôd think, ‚Äúwell proving it in criminal court must be virtually impossible‚Äù. So this could act as a deterrent for genuine abuse victims who would otherwise speak up. The judge probably imagined he was doing something noble and necessary for the greater good, and was justified in making Depp the sacrificial lamb because in his eyes it‚Äôs only a spoilt lying drug addict with a malicious desire to exploit the courts to get one over on his ex. Equity‚Äôs ‚Äúclean hands‚Äù attitude seems to be pervasive in the courts of this country. It‚Äôs this ‚Äúwell you haven‚Äôt been a model citizen and if you‚Äôre going to misbehave then don‚Äôt expect any help from us‚Äù. It‚Äôs that aggravating, passively resistant attitude based on this idea they seem to have that they‚Äôre doing you a favour by listening to your case, that access to justice is gratuitous and that there is something audacious in an attempt to make use of the justice system or commencing litigation. Another frustrating part of this was the UK charity Refuge released a statement regarding the trial; they talked about how victims (in reference to Amber) are constantly told that they won't be believed and how this is proof that money fame and power (aka Johnny) cannot be used to silence women. This would have been such a powerful message but, when used in reference to a ruling that was very clearly biased and poorly-handled (also when they seem to ignore the fact that Amber is also rather rich and famous), it sounds ironic at best and appalling at worst.

If anything, this is a step backwards for abuse victims as a whole (because this showed that evidence can be discounted due to bias and that judges can just make assumptions about your character, the circumstances of injuries and testimonies on a whim, thus reinforcing the mindset that you may not be believed), but if you want to focus specifically on women as victims, it's even worse. I can already see the terrible handling of this case being used to try and accuse women of being liars regardless of outcome and the idea of that makes me so angry. Even if Amber was innocent, people would still easily use these inconsistencies to discredit the case and her, so it wasn't even really a victory in that sense either.

It's infuriating that one man's strange decisions have meant that, no matter what happens going forward, there's very little hope of either side ever being believed by outsiders because of how much can be contested and cherry-picked (which normally wouldn't matter in the long run, but their living is based on being in the public eye). comment: To reiterate Pluto's comment about restraining orders and to extend them a bit, DO NOT have unsupervised contact with anyone who takes a restraining order against you! This is true for many jurisdictions in the US, Canada, GB, Australia and likely true for much of the rest of the world who uses them. There have been several cases in the US and Canada where the person the order was taken against was tracked by the person who took the order (some of them likely under false pretenses, although proving that is difficult at best) through locators (phone location or GPS devices) so they could be in the same restaurant, theater or other venue that the ordered person was closer than the restriction proximity in the order and the protected person could have the ordered person arrested and jailed for a "created" situation.  This makes for some very strong evidence against the ordered person in family court and child custody cases and, since the order commonly puts all the non-contact requirements on the ordered person, can make for some damming evidence against them.

comment: Thanks so much for this video. Does anyone feel incredibly uncomfortable/unable to comment about Johnny/the case after this verdict?  A number of my friends have made casual comments against Depp these past days, particularly following his leaving of the Fantastic Beasts franchise (one in particular who was following, and though not a fan of his acting, was supporting Depp having heard the tapes during the trial and then following the trial.  Now, with this result she has reverted to negative comments towards Depp/Depp's career.) The decision has been made and what does it say about me if I am unable to fully accept it?  Will I not accept it because I know the opposite to be true?  How can I *know* that?  Or will I not accept it because I believe I know better than a Judge?  Or do I just simply not want it to be true?  Neither say anything good about me.  What upsets me most about the trial is not even the result, but the fact that this is a libel case, yet the judgment reads like a indictment of Johnny's alleged (but deemed true) crimes with the Judge literally saying he believes it most likely all of Johnny's alleged deeds are true and that Amber did nothing wrong as far as he can think (which in fact surely shouldn't be part of the verdict as does it even matter for this case what Amber did or didn't do?  Yet still she can be deemed innocent?)  Though it isn't a case of Johnny's guilt - that is how the verdict reads to me.  I feel silenced and don't even know how I could talk about it in any case without my own prejudice because of course I have personal bias.  I always try to be objective of thought, but I am just a person and I cannot claim that to be fully true.  Anyway, whatever the result might be, I hope Depp is able to and does appeal and I certainly feel for him right now.
